ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: The ability to compose a close analysis paper based on very focused passages. Meta interpretation of philosophy across the western canon. Most importantly doing quick logical and critical thinking in tackling certain parts of the text in discussion seminars inspired by other's ideas.
An understanding of the history of human philosophical thought, argument reconstruction, analysis, and critique, and comprehension of the continuities across the history of human thought.
How to effectively structure an argument and how to time manage writing an essay.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: Great content; good pacing; not sure if the way of organizing seminars is the most efficien.

Strength: a pungent potpourri of the ancient philosophy texts. Professor Maxwell is great in spiking up conversations during seminars and even more of an expert in guiding people voice their own precious analysis. 

Weakness: Common to all DS classes. All of the texts could be food for thought enough for an entire semester but we dapple through them with only a week or so.

This course covers the greats of classical and neoclassical thought - all the household names, and then some.  In that respect, it is a fantastic survey course that exposes you to philosophy that is deeply relevant to this day.  However, the nature of such a broad survey course means that it moves through content at a breakneck pace.  A lot slips between the cracks at such a speed, especially towards the end of the course.

This course provides a very broad overview of ancient philosophy, but I think it misses out on some pretty important things, while focusing on less interesting ideas. Our reading of the Stoic philosophers, for example, skips over the very advanced logic, and we instead read Stoic ethics, which I personally found kind of bland and uninteresting.

Strengths:
Writing philosophy papers meant learning a very specific style of writing which will likely be helpful for the future. 


Weaknesses: 
Having more clarity in what specific sections of the text to focus on. Although we had general assignments on what to read per week, having what we should read per specific day in the syllabus would be helpful.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: To anyone interested in philosophy, yes; don't think one can plausibly go into philosophy without reading the books involved in this course.

DS is a whole package and no in-betweens. It's like driving the car for the first time and choosing to start with Manhattan. I mean sure, bruises and bumps and weird cryptic hoofs from people triple your age with accents from all over the world are bound to follow you, but hell, you get to see times square and Hudson river and all the hits.

Yes.  These ideas have shaped human thought since their existence and continue to do so today.  If you do not enjoy reading, writing, and discussing, do not sign up for Directed Studies.  But if you want to learn about the history of human thought and be able to participate more fully in any sort of philosophical conversation or discussion, this course will give you the tools and knowledge to do so in a beautiful way.
I would recommend this course. The professor is very supportive and the essays taught me a lot about time management and constructing arguments, both of which are very useful for future courses.
